context_evidences: - But it perhaps has been the new life that The Office found on Netflix that has transformed the show into the meme-generating viral juggernaut it’s known as today. Although memes inspired by The Office were popular throughout the show’s run, as one of the most-watched shows on Netflix’s at the height of meme culture, it has become a true beacon of online humor. Reference: https://time.com/5763852/best-the-office-memes/ published on 2020-01-28 14:32:02

- Memes are the fundamental unit of cultural evolution and have been left upon the periphery of cognitive neuroscience due to their inexact definition and the consequent presumption that they are impossible to measure. Here it is argued that although a precise definition of memes is rather difficult it does not preclude highly controlled experiments studying the neural substrates of their initiation and replication. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3118481/ published on 2011-09-10 00:00:00

- And in 2017, it’s clear that the doomsday crew vastly underestimated internet users’ creativity. Increased mobility and access across platforms and communities has brought to the surface some of the funniest and weirdest content the web has ever known. Reference: https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/12/a-unified-theory-of-meme-death/546866/ published on 2017-12-07 08:00:00

- But Chris Torres, the creator of Nyan cat , anticipated that the break from the old-school would be a good thing. “The internet doesn’t really need to have its hand held anymore with websites that choose memes for them,” he told The Daily Dot ’s Fernando Alfonso III in 2014. “As long as there is creativity in this world then they are never going away. This may just be the calm before the storm of amazing new material.” Reference: https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/12/a-unified-theory-of-meme-death/546866/ published on 2017-12-07 08:00:00

- The word “meme” was coined by Richard Dawkins in 1976. He argued that virality didn’t just apply to infectious diseases, but also in anthropological settings. He defined a meme as any shareable cultural artifact that spreads through a culture like wildfire. Reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2018/07/19/more-than-a-trend-meme-marketing-is-here-to-stay/ published on 2018-07-19 08:00:00

- Because as long as the absurd workplace comedy of The Office remains relatable to the modern world, people will keep watching and the memes will keep flowing. Reference: https://time.com/5763852/best-the-office-memes/ published on 2020-01-28 14:32:02

- Today, memes have a specific connotation in our digital environment. What makes memes so special is their way of communicating attitudes, feelings and situations. Because of their popularity, it comes as no surprise that brands want a piece of this pie. Reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2018/07/19/more-than-a-trend-meme-marketing-is-here-to-stay/ published on 2018-07-19 08:00:00

- A meme is a replicator, a cultural unit operating under Darwinian evolutionary principles analogous to a gene, but a distinct replicator in its own right (Dawkins, 1976 ; Goodenough and Dawkins, 1994 ). A meme in layman terms is a concept or idea, embodied by a word, a phrase, a riff, image, or gesture. A meme “exists” in the world of ideas and replicates by imitation. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3118481/ published on 2011-09-10 00:00:00
correction_response:
This tweet is somewhat misleading. While individual memes may lose popularity over time, they don't have a set "expiration date". The lifespan of a meme can vary greatly, with some lasting years and others only a few weeks. This is often dependent on cultural context and trends at the time. For example, memes inspired by The Office have remained popular due to the show's continued relevance and popularity on Netflix. However, to effectively use a meme, it's important to be aware of what's currently trending. 
References: 
https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/12/a-unified-theory-of-meme-death/546866/
https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2018/07/19/more-than-a-trend-meme-marketing-is-here-to-stay/
https://time.com/5763852/best-the-office-memes/
note_1_text: This is an opinion and not a fact.  Memes do not have expiration dates. They may, in fact, become irrelevant, but that is not an expiration date.  People should be allowed to see memes and decide for themselves if they are relevant.
note_2_text: Memes do not have expiration dates.

refute_evidences: - Crying Jordan lasted years; did Damn Daniel even last two weeks? Salt Bae took over social media in January 2017, but was quickly overshadowed by gifs of Drew Scanlon (“white guy blinking”) and rapper Conceited (“black guy duck face”), which lasted throughout the spring. Reference: https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/12/a-unified-theory-of-meme-death/546866/ published on 2017-12-07 08:00:00

- While internet memes categorically remain alive and well, individual memes do seem to die off faster than in Poole’s “good ol’ days.” They just don’t last like they used to: Compare the lifespans of say, Bad Luck Brian to Arthur’s clenched fist or confused Mr. Krabs. Reference: https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/12/a-unified-theory-of-meme-death/546866/ published on 2017-12-07 08:00:00

- Watch your timing. Some memes have been around for years, while others are fleeting, like Kenneth Bone during the presidential debate . If you use an existing meme, make sure it’s still trendy. If you create your own, make sure the cultural climate is right. Otherwise, you’ll come off as tone deaf and out of touch. Reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2018/07/19/more-than-a-trend-meme-marketing-is-here-to-stay/ published on 2018-07-19 08:00:00

- Memes can have either a long or short life cycle. To effectively use an existing meme, brands have to keep their ear to the ground to know what’s trending. Reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2018/07/19/more-than-a-trend-meme-marketing-is-here-to-stay/ published on 2018-07-19 08:00:00
